name: Abdominal pain, unspecified
extras__hint: Please consult with your doctor if the pain lasts more than 24 hours.

questions.question_text: Do you have generalized pain?
Do you have localized pain?
Do you have cramping?
Do you have a sharp localized pain in your stomach or abrupt urniary pain ?
Do you have a fever?
Do you have bloody stool?
Do you have nausea and vomiting that does not resolve?
Have you lost any weight?
Do you have yellowish skin?
Is your abdomen tender?
Is your abdomen swollen?

causes: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (swelling in the belly's main artery)
Cancer of the stomach, pancreas, liver, bile duct, gallbladder, or immune cells
Low blood flow to your intestines caused by a blocked blood vessel
Ectopic pregnancy (when a fertilized eggs grows outside the uterus, for example, in a Fallopian tube)
overview: Appendix pain is typically described as pain or discomfort in the abdominal area (the belly), in the lower right side, where the appendix is located. Medically speaking, there is no such thing as appendix pain, even though the affected person may describe or experience it as such. The correct term is abdominal pain, which is a symptom of both serious and non-serious medical issues, such as gastroenteritis, gas, hepatitis, irritable bowel syndrome, gallstones and indeed acute appendicitis.

treatment.outline: Relief from abdominal pain will generally depend on its underlying cause.

name: Acne
extras__hint: Please schedule an appointment with your family doctor or a dermatologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have any scars?
If you're a woman do you have excessive growth of dark or coarse hair in a male-like pattern - face, chest and back ?
Do you have blackheads -  small black or yellowish bumps that develop on the skin; they're not filled with dirt, but are black because the inner lining of the hair follicle produces colour?
Do you have whiteheads -  have a similar appearance to blackheads, but may be firmer and will not empty when squeezed?
Do you have papules -  small red bumps that may feel tender or sore?
Do you have pustules -  similar to papules, but have a white tip in the centre, caused by a build-up of pus?
Do you have nodules -  large hard lumps that build up beneath the surface of the skin and can be painful?
Do you have cysts -  the most severe type of spot caused by acne; they're large pus-filled lumps that look similar to boils and carry the greatest risk of causing permanent scarring?

causes: Abnormal keratinisation of the hair follicles (hereditary)
Increased sensitivity of the sebaceous glands to male hormones
Prolonged use of systemic and topical steroids e.g.
Anabolic steroids such as danazol, stanozolol and nandrolone
Use of pomades, especially products that contain lanolin, petrolatum, vegetable oils, butyl stearate, lauryl alcohol and oleic acid
Contraceptive agents: medroxyprogesterone injection, implanted or intrauterine progesterone, and oral contraceptives
overview: Acne is a skin condition that occurs when your hair follicles become plugged with oil and dead skin cells. It causes whiteheads, blackheads or pimples.

treatment.outline: The treatment of acne depends on the severity of the disease.
self_care: Wash problem areas with a gentle cleanser
Try over-the-counter acne products to dry excess oil and promote peeling
Protect your skin from the sun
Avoid friction or pressure on your skin
Avoid touching or picking acne-prone areas
treatment.non_emergency: If you've tried over-the-counter (nonprescription) acne products for several weeks and they haven't helped, ask your doctor about prescription-strength medications.

name: Acute bronchitis
extras__hint: See your family doctor. You may also need to consult a pulmonologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have a fever?
Do you have an excessively runny nose or excess of fluid or discharge from the nose?
Do you hear wheezing sounds when you take deep breaths and exhale?

causes: Viruses e.g. Influenza virus, Corona virus (common cold)
Bacteria e.g. Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenza, Moraxella catarrhalis, Staph. aureus (tends to cause post-influenza chest infections, including bronchitis)
overview: Acute bronchitis, also commonly called a chest cold, is a short-term inflammation of the bronchial tubes which carry air to and from the lungs. Its principal symptom is coughing.

treatment.outline: Most cases of acute bronchitis get better without treatment, usually within a couple of weeks.
treatment.non_emergency: Because most cases of bronchitis are caused by viral infections, antibiotics aren't effective. However, if your doctor suspects that you have a bacterial infection, he or she may prescribe an antibiotic.

name: Acute otitis media
extras__hint: Please see your family doctor or an ENT specialist.

questions.question_text: Are any of your eardrums red?
Do you have discharge from your ear?
Do you have an occasionally inflamed throat?
Have you suffered a blow to the head or stuck an object in your ear that might have appeared to have gone too deep?

overview: Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear. Typical signs may include pain in the ear, fever, difficulty hearing and difficulty sleeping.

treatment.outline: The main treatment of middle ear infections is pain relief. Warm compresses or pain medication (such as ibuprofen and paracetamol) are both helpful for managing ear pain. Antibiotics are often not needed to treat middle ear infections, but may be offered to people with complicated ear infections or other medical issues.
treatment.non_emergency: Warm compresses or pain medication (such as ibuprofen and paracetamol) help in managing ear pain. Antibiotics may be offered to people with complicated ear infections or other medical issues.

name: Acute rhinosinusitis
extras__hint: Please consult with your family doctor in case your symptoms get worse or do not relieve in 5 days.

questions.question_text: Do you have yellow or green thick nasal discharge, which may be foul smelling?
Do you have bad breath?
Have you had a fever lasting more than 10 to 14 days?
Do you have tenderness above and below the eyes, when you bend over or when these areas are tapped lightly?

overview: Acute sinusitis causes the spaces inside your nose (sinuses) to become inflamed and swollen. This interferes with drainage and causes mucus to build up. With acute sinusitis, it might be difficult to breathe through your nose. The area around your eyes and face might feel swollen, and you might have throbbing facial pain or a headache.

treatment.outline: Most cases of acute sinusitis get better on their own. Self-care techniques are usually all you need to ease symptoms.
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor may recommend treatments to help relieve sinusitis symptoms, including: saline nasal spray, which you spray into your nose several times a day to rinse your nasal passages. Nasal corticosteroids which are nasal sprays which help prevent and treat inflammation. Decongestants which are available in over-the-counter (OTC) and prescription liquids, tablets and nasal sprays. Use nasal decongestants for only a few days.

name: Acute streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis
extras__hint: Please consult your family doctor.

questions.question_text: Do you have throat pain that usually comes on quickly?
Does it hurt when you swallow?
Are your tonsils red and swollen?
Do you have tiny red spots on the area at the back of the roof of the mouth?
Do you have swollen, tender lymph nodes in your neck?
Do you have a fever?
Do you have a headache?
Do you have a rash?
Are you nauseous or vomiting?
Do you have general body aches?

overview: Strep throat is a bacterial infection that can make your throat feel sore and scratchy. Strep throat accounts for only a small portion of sore throats. If untreated, strep throat can cause complications, such as kidney inflammation or rheumatic fever.

treatment.outline: Medications are available to cure strep throat, relieve its symptoms, and prevent its complications and spread.
treatment.non_emergency: If your doctor diagnoses you or your child with strep throat, your doctor will likely prescribe an oral antibiotic. If taken within 48 hours of the onset of the illness, antibiotics reduce the duration and severity of symptoms, as well as the risk of complications and the likelihood that infection will spread to others.

name: Acute viral tonsillopharyngitis
extras__hint: Please consult with your family doctor in case your symptoms get worse or do not relieve in 1-2 days.

questions.question_text: Do you have discomfort when swallowing?
Do you have a fever?
Do you have joint pain or muscle aches?
Do you have a sore throat?
Do you have tender swollen lymph nodes in the neck?

overview: Tonsillopharyngitis is usually viral, most often caused by the common cold viruses (adenovirus, rhinovirus, influenza, coronavirus, and respiratory syncytial virus), but occasionally by Epstein-Barr virus, herpes simplex virus, cytomegalovirus, or HIV.

treatment.outline: There's no specific treatment for tonsillitis, but you may be able to reduce the symptoms by.
treatment.non_emergency: Take paracetamol or ibuprofen to help relieve pain, drink plenty of fluids, get plenty of rest. If test results show that your tonsillitis is caused by a bacterial infection, a short course of oral antibiotics may be prescribed. If oral antibiotics aren't effective at treating bacterial tonsillitis, intravenous antibiotics (given directly into a vein) may be needed in hospital.

name: Adenomyosis
extras__hint: You need to consult with a gynecologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding?
Do you have severe cramping or sharp, knifelike pelvic pain during menstruation?
Do you have chronic pelvic pain?
Do you have discomfort or pain during sex that's felt deep inside the pelvis?

overview: Adenomyosis (ad-uh-no-my-O-sis) occurs when the tissue that normally lines the uterus (endometrial tissue) grows into the muscular wall of the uterus. An enlarged uterus and painful, heavy periods can result. Doctors aren't sure what causes adenomyosis, but the disease usually resolves after menopause. For women who have severe discomfort from adenomyosis, hormonal treatments can help. Removal of the uterus (hysterectomy) cures adenomyosis

treatment.outline: Adenomyosis often goes away after menopause, so treatment might depend on how close you are to that stage of life.
self_care: Use a heating pad on your abdomen
Take over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB)
treatment.emergency: If your pain is severe and no other treatments have worked, your doctor might suggest surgery to remove your uterus. Removing your ovaries isn't necessary to control adenomyosis.
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment options for adenomyosis include: anti-inflammatory drugs to control the pain or hormone medications to lessen bleeding and pain associated with adenomyosis.

name: Adnexitis
extras__hint: You should make an appointment with a gynecologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have pain around the pelvis or lower tummy?
Do you have discomfort or pain during sex that's felt deep inside the pelvis?
Do you feel pain when you pee?
Do you have bleeding between periods and after sex?
Do you have heavy periods?
Do you have painful periods?
Do you have unusual vaginal discharge, especially if it's yellow or green?
Do you have severe pain in the tummy?
Do you have a high temperature - 37.2°C or higher?

overview: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection of the female reproductive organs. It most often occurs when sexually transmitted bacteria spread from your vagina to your uterus, fallopian tubes or ovaries.

treatment.outline: Prompt treatment with medicine can get rid of the infection that causes pelvic inflammatory disease. But there's no way to reverse any scarring or damage to the reproductive tract that PID might have caused.
treatment.emergency: In particularly severe cases of PID, you may have to be admitted to hospital to receive antibiotics through a drip in your arm (intravenously).
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment with antibiotics needs to be started quickly, before the results of the swabs are available. PID is usually caused by a variety of different bacteria, even in cases where chlamydia, gonorrhoea or mycoplasma genitalium is identified. This means you'll be given a mixture of antibiotics to cover the most likely infections. If you have pain around your pelvis or tummy, you can take painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen while you're being treated with antibiotics.

name: Allergic conjunctivitis
extras__hint: You should consult an allergist or ophthalmologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have red itchy eyes?
Do you feel a burning sensation in your eye or do your eyes feel gritty?
Is there pus that sticks to lashes?
Do you have watery eyes?

causes: Pollens, including grass, tree and other plant pollens
overview: Pink eye (conjunctivitis) is an inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane (conjunctiva) that lines your eyelid and covers the white part of your eyeball.

treatment.outline: Pink eye treatment is usually focused on symptom relief. Your doctor may recommend using artificial tears, cleaning your eyelids with a wet cloth, and applying cold or warm compresses several times daily.
self_care: Apply a compress to your eyes
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor may prescribe one of many different types of eyedrops for people with allergies.

name: Allergic rhinitis
extras__hint: Please see an allergist.

questions.question_text: Are you sneezing?
Do you have a stuffy, runny or itchy nose?
Do you have red, itchy and watery eyes?
Do you have a cough, caused by a mucus build up at the back of the throat, also known as postnasal drip?
Do you have swelling around the eyes?
Do you have a sore throat?
Do you have a headache?
Do you have a tight feeling in the chest?
Are you wheezing?
Do you have shortness of breath?

causes: Grain dust affecting farmers and agricultural workers
Latex affecting medical workers wearing gloves
Fish and seafood proteins affecting factory and kitchen workers
overview: Allergic rhinitis is a condition in which inflammation develops inside the nose; this is caused by an allergic reaction to particles in the air. These particles, which are otherwise harmless to the body, are known as allergens. Typical symptoms of allergic rhinitis include:Allergic rhinitis is one of the most common chronic diseases and is estimated to affect between 40 and 60 million people in the U.S.Allergic rhinitis can be differentiated into three types:Read more about hay fever. There is no cure for allergic rhinitis, but the effects of the condition can be lessened with the use of nasal sprays and antihistamine medications. A doctor may recommend immunotherapy - a treatment option that can provide long-term relief. Steps can also be taken to avoid allergens. The severity of allergic rhinitis can also change over the course of an affected persons life. This means, for example, that the effects of allergic rhinitis may fade during puberty, or that an affected person may develop a sensitivity to new allergens during adulthood.

treatment.outline: There is no cure for allergic rhinitis but its effects can be lessened by medication in the short-term, and, in some cases, sensitivity to the allergen can be reduced.
treatment.non_emergency: It's best to limit your exposure to substances that cause your hay fever as much as possible. If your hay fever isn't too severe, over-the-counter medications may be enough to relieve symptoms. For worse symptoms, you may need prescription medications.

name: Anxiety disorder
extras__hint: Please consult a psychologist or psychiatrist.

questions.question_text: Are you restless?
Do you get the sweats?
Do you feel like you are in a constantily agited state?
Do you have a rapid hearbeat?
Do your muscles contract and shake involuntarily?
Do you find it hard to concentrate?
Have you been losing sleep, or waking in the night with bad dreams?
Are you constantly worrying or having negative thoughts?
Are you feeling tense and fidgety, or using the toilet often?
Do you have the urge to cry often?
Do you have a tendency to get overly attached or emotionally dependent on someone or something?
Have you been complaining of tummy aches and feeling unwell?

overview: Experiencing occasional anxiety is a normal part of life. However, people with anxiety disorders frequently have intense, excessive and persistent worry and fear about everyday situations. Often, anxiety disorders involve repeated episodes of sudden feelings of intense anxiety and fear or terror that reach a peak within minutes (panic attacks).

treatment.outline: The two main treatments for anxiety disorders are psychotherapy and medications. You may benefit most from a combination of the two. It may take some trial and error to discover which treatments work best for you.
self_care: Quit smoking and cut back or quit drinking caffeinated beverages
Use stress management and relaxation techniques
treatment.non_emergency: Also known as talk therapy or psychological counseling, psychotherapy involves working with a therapist to reduce your anxiety symptoms. It can be an effective treatment for anxiety.

name: Appendicitis
extras__hint: Please report promptly to the nearest hospital.

questions.question_text: Do you feel a sudden pain that begins on the right side of the lower abdomen?
Do you feel a sudden pain that begins around your navel and often shifts to your lower right abdomen?
Do you have pain that worsens if you cough, walk or make other jarring movements?
Are you nauseous or vomiting?
Have you lost your appetite?
Do you have a low-grade fever (between 37°C and 38.3°C)?
Do you have constipation or diarrhea?
Is your adbomen bloated?
Have you been passing gas frequently?

causes: Infections caused by bacteria or, less commonly, viruses
Swollen lymph tissue in the area, more common among people with disorders that lead to inflammation in the bowel, such as diverticulitis, ulcerative colitis, or Crohns disease
Tumors of the appendix, although these are rare
Intestinal worms, although this is uncommon
Foreign bodies, such as fruit seed residue, although this is very rare
overview: Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix, a finger-shaped pouch that projects from your colon on the lower right side of your abdomen. Appendicitis causes pain in your lower right abdomen. However, in most people, pain begins around the navel and then moves. As inflammation worsens, appendicitis pain typically increases and eventually becomes severe.

treatment.outline: Appendicitis treatment usually involves surgery to remove the inflamed appendix. Before surgery you may be given a dose of antibiotics to treat infection.
self_care: Support your abdomen when you cough
Call your doctor if pain medications aren't helping
Get up and move when you're ready
Discuss returning to work or school with your doctor
treatment.emergency: An appendectomy can be performed to remove the appendix.

name: Asthma
extras__hint: Please consult a general practitioner or a pulmonologist.

questions.question_text: Is your breathing abnormally rapid and often shallow?
Do you find it difficult to catch your breath and have to strain your neck and/or abdominal muscles to breath ?
Are you wheezing - hear whistling sound when you breathe ?
Do you find it diffcult to finish a complete sentence in one breathe?
Do you have a rapid pulse > 110/minute in adults and adolescents or >130/ minute in children 2-5 years?
Does the skin around your lips, mouth, palms of your hand, or around your eyes have a bluish or greyish discoloration
Do you feel drowsy and tired?
Does your chest feel tight, like a band is tightening around it?

causes: Allergens e.g. house dust mite, cockroach droppings, grass, pollen and animal hair
Environmental factors e.g. air pollution, climatic changes, strong scents and smoke (including cigarette smoke and car fumes)
Drugs e.g. aspirin, NSAIDS and beta-blockers such as propranolol
Occupational exposure to industrial chemicals, dust and drug manufacturing
overview: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, a whistling sound (wheezing) when you breathe out and shortness of breath.

treatment.outline: Prevention and long-term control are key to stopping asthma attacks before they start. Treatment usually involves learning to recognize your triggers, taking steps to avoid triggers and tracking your breathing to make sure your medications are keeping symptoms under control. In case of an asthma flare-up, you may need to use a quick-relief inhaler.
self_care: Cover your nose and mouth and if it's cold
Control heartburn and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment usually involves learning to recognize your triggers, taking steps to avoid triggers and tracking your breathing to make sure your medications are keeping symptoms under control. In case of an asthma flare-up, you may need to use a quick-relief inhaler.

name: Atopic dermatitis
extras__hint: Please see an allergist or dermatologist.

questions.question_text: Are the patches oozing a lot of fluid?
Do you have a yellow crust developing over the patches?
Is the skin around the patches becoming hot, swollen and tender or painful?
Are you feeling sick?
Are you feeling hot or shivery?
Are you feeling unwell?
Are your existing symptoms getting rapidly worse?
Do you have discharge from your skin?
Do you have increasing pain?
Are you feeling generally unwell?

causes: Irritating substances, such as certain clothing or chemicals
overview: Atopic dermatitis (eczema) is a condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever.

treatment.outline: There is no cure for atopic dermatitis, meaning treatment is aimed at managing the symptoms. In many cases, symptoms will naturally improve with age.
self_care: Moisturize your skin at least twice a day
Apply an anti-itch cream to the affected area
Take an oral allergy or anti-itch medication
Choose mild soaps without dyes or perfumes
treatment.non_emergency: The two main treatment methods for atopic dermatitis are: emollients and steroid creams and ointments. Other treatment methods incled antihistamine tablets, ultraviolet light therapy, immunosuppressive drugs and wet dressings
medication: Creams that control itching and help repair the skin

name: Bacterial gastroenteritis
extras__hint: You should see a family doctor.

questions.question_text: Do you have diarrhea?
Do you have abdominal (belly) discomfort, pain or cramps?
Does your belly feel swollen after eaten?
Have you lost your appetite?
Are you nauseous or vomiting?
Do you have the fever and chills?
Do you have body aches?
Do you have a headache?
Are you feeling dizy?
Do you have a general feeling of weakness?
Is there blood in your stool (feces)?
Have you been peeing regularly?
Are you aware if you have a weakened immune system or immuno-compromised in any shape?
Do you have a chronic condition such as inflammatory bowel disease or diabetes?

causes: Unhygienic food preparation, e.g. a cook not washing their hands after going to the toilet, or using the same cutting boards for both meat and salads
Raw or undercooked meat, eggs and fish
overview: Bacterial gastroenteritis is a type of gastroenteritis  a common condition sometimes called stomach flu or food poisoning. Gastroenteritis is the result of irritation and inflammation in the stomach and intestines. It can have many different possible causes, including infection with a virus, such as rotavirus (see viral gastroenteritis), bacteria or parasites. When caused by bacteria, it is called bacterial gastroenteritis. The condition can affect adults and children. Symptoms of bacterial gastroenteritis can range from mild to severe and vary depending on the type of bacteria that have caused the infection. The main symptom is usually diarrhea. Other symptoms may include: Bacterial stomach flu can be caused by a number of different types of bacteria, which are most often spread through contaminated food and beverages. Depending on the source of infection, a large group of people may develop symptoms of bacterial gastroenteritis, or food poisoning, at the same time. While it can be very unpleasant, most cases of bacterial gastroenteritis can be treated at home, and clear up within a few days without causing complications. Treatment for bacterial gastroenteritis typically involves: Antibiotics are generally only recommended for more severe types of bacterial gastroenteritis.

treatment.outline: Most cases of bacterial gastroenteritis clear up without specific medical treatment. As long as symptoms are not severe and there are no signs of dehydration, a person can generally treat bacterial gastroenteritis in an adult or child at home.
self_care: Consuming plenty of fluids in the form of water or oral rehydration drinks; at the very least, small sips should be taken between being sick or having bowel movements
Eating light meals when the appetite returns; plain foods like bread and rice may be helpful
Taking an antidiarrheal medication, e.g. loperamide, only when necessary and there is no fever, and no blood or mucus is present in the stool
Taking antiemetic (anti-nausea) medicine for nausea and vomiting, when necessary
treatment.non_emergency: Most cases of bacterial gastroenteritis clear up without specific medical treatment. As long as symptoms are not severe and there are no signs of dehydration, a person can generally treat bacterial gastroenteritis in an adult or child at home.

name: Bartholin's abscess
extras__hint: You should see a gynecologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have pain in the affected area?
Do you have a high temperature?
Are you generally feeling unwell?

overview: A Bartholin's abscess can occur when one of the Bartholin's glands, located on either side of the vaginal opening, develop an infection. When the gland is blocked, a cyst will usually form. If the cyst becomes infected, it can lead to a Bartholin's abscess. A Bartholin's abscess can be more than an inch in diameter. It usually causes significant pain.

treatment.outline: Often a Bartholin's cyst requires no treatment — especially if the cyst causes no signs or symptoms.
self_care: Daily soaking in warm water, several times a day, may be adequate to resolve an infected Bartholin's cyst or abscess.

Using a mix of tea tree and castor oil as a topical ointment on the abscess may promote drainage. Tea tree oil is known for its antibacterial properties, which may help clear an infection. Castor oil is thought to promote blood circulation in the affected area, which can reduce inflammation. You can apply the tea tree and castor oil with a piece of gauze. Adding a hot compress on top of the gauze may make this remedy even more effective.
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment options your doctor may recommend include: Sitz baths, surgical drainage of the cyst, antibiotics or marsupialization.

name: Blepharitis
extras__hint: You should consult an ophthalmologist.

questions.question_text: Are your eyelids sore?
Do your eyes itch?
Do you have a gritty feeling in your eyes?
Do you have flakes or crusts around the roots of your eyelashes?
Do you have red eyes or eyelids?
Are your eyelids sticking together in the morning when you wake up?

overview: Blepharitis causes red, swollen and itchy eyelids. It can normally be treated by washing your eyelids every day. The condition is not usually serious, but can lead to other problems, such as dry eyes, cysts and conjunctivitis, especially if it's not treated.

treatment.outline: Self-care measures, such as washing your eyes and using warm compresses, might be all that's needed for most cases of blepharitis. If self-care measures aren't enough, your doctor might suggest prescription treatments.
treatment.non_emergency: If self-care measures aren't enough, your doctor might suggest prescription treatments including: medications that fight infection, medications to control infalmmation, mediaction that affect the immune system and treatments for underlying conditions. Other treatment options include using intense pulsed light to unclog the glands.

name: Cervical strain
extras__hint: Try available painkiller remedies. If you don't get better in following days, please visit your GP.

questions.question_text: Do you have any neck pain or stiffness?
Do you have pain in your shoulders or upper back?
Do you have muscle spasms - involuntary contractions of a muscle?
Do you have a headache, often starting at the base of the neck?
Are you irritabile, having trouble concentrating, or sleeplessness?
Do you have numbness in your arm or hand?
Do you have a tingling sensation or weakness in your arm?

overview: Cervical strain is a medical term for neck pain. The neck has several layers of muscles. These are connected with tendons to the cervical spine and other bones. Neck pain is often the result of injury to these muscles and tendons.

treatment.outline: This problem often gets better on its own. Treatments aim to reduce pain and inflammation and increase the range of motion of the neck.
treatment.non_emergency: Possible treatments include: over-the-counter or prescription medicine, muscle relaxants, stretching exercises to decrease neck stiffness, massages to decrease neck stiffness or a cold or heat pack to help reduce pain and swelling.

name: Chalazion
extras__hint: You need to see an ophthalmologist.

questions.question_text: Is there a bump on your eyelid, usually on the upper lid?
Do you have any mild irritation, causing your eyes to water?
Do you have blurred vision?

overview: A chalazion is a slowly developing lump that forms due to blockage and swelling of an oil gland in the eyelid. A chalazion often starts out as a very small, red, tender, swollen area of the eyelid and is generally not an infection.

treatment.outline: Most chalazions require minimal medical treatment and clear up on their own in a few weeks to a month.
self_care: Place a warm washcloth over your closed eye
treatment.emergency: If the chalazion does not go away after several weeks, it may require medical treatment, which may include an incision to drain or an injection of steroids to reduce the inflammation and swelling.
treatment.non_emergency: Apply warm compresses to the eyelid for 10 to 15 minutes, 4 to 6 times a day for several days. The warm compresses may help soften the hardened oil that is blocking the ducts and allow drainage and healing. Gently massage the external eyelids several minutes each day to help promote drainage. Once the chalazion drains on its own, keep the area clean, and keep hands away from the eyes. Again, do not attempt to squeeze the chalazion, as it may inadvertently cause more damage.

name: Chest pain, unspecified
extras__hint: Please consult with your doctor if the pain lasts more than 24 hours.

questions.question_text: Do you have an unhealthy pale appearance?
Is your breathing difficult or laboured?
Do you have pneumonia?
Are you sweating?
Do you have a pulse - rate high, low or normal; regular or irregular?
Does your chest expand unequally?
Are your breath sounds reduced?
Are your breath sounds harsh and poor?
Are your breath sounds audible and raspy?
Is your abdomen tender?
Is your abdomen tensed?
Are your bowel sounuds reduced?
Is your chest wall tender?

causes: Sickle cell disease - acute chest syndrome
overview: Chest pain is one of the most common reasons that people visit the emergency room. Chest pain varies depending on the person. It also varies in: quality, intensity, duration, location. It may feel like a sharp, stabbing pain or a dull ache. It may be a sign of a serious heart-related problem. Many common causes that aren't life-threatening may also have caused it.

treatment.outline: Treatment varies depending on what's causing your chest pain.
treatment.emergency: If your chest pain is caused by a blockage in an artery feeding your heart, your doctor will perform an Angioplasty and stent placement. Other procedures include a Bypass surgery, a Dissection repair to repair the rupturing of the artery that carries blood from the heart or a lung reinflation to reinflate a collapsed lung.
treatment.non_emergency: Drugs used to treat some of the most common causes of chest pain include: Artery relaxers, Aspirin, Thrombolytic drugs, Blood thinners, Acid-suppressing medications or Antidepressants.

name: Chronic constipation
extras__hint: Please visit your family doctor or a gastroenterologist.

questions.question_text: Are your bowel sounds frequently high pitched?*
Are your bowel sounds absent?*
Is your abodmen tender and tensed?
Have you have had a poo less than 3 times during the last week?
Is your poo often large and dry, hard or lumpy?
Do you strain when you poo?

causes: Ignoring the urge to defaecate e.g. due to immobility
Drugs e.g. atropine, codeine, morphine, tricyclic antidepressants, disopyramide
Lazy bowel from chronic laxative use including 'herbal' preparations
Anal fissure and other painful perianal lesions
Carcinoma of the rectum and sigmoid colon
Ogilvie syndrome) following immobility from any cause
overview: Chronic constipation is infrequent bowel movements or difficult passage of stools that persists for several weeks or longer. Constipation is generally described as having fewer than three bowel movements a week.

treatment.outline: Treatment for chronic constipation usually begins with diet and lifestyle changes meant to increase the speed at which stool moves through your intestines. If those changes don't help, your doctor may recommend medications or surgery.
self_care: Exercise most days of the week
Don't ignore the urge to have a bowel movement
treatment.emergency: Surgery may be an option if you have tried other treatments and your chronic constipation is caused by a blockage, rectocele or stricture.
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor may recommend diet and lifestyle changes meant to increase the speed at which stool moves through your intestines. If those changes don't help your doctor may recommend medications such as laxatives.
medication: Medications that draw water into your intestines

name: Common cold
extras__hint: If your symptoms get worse, see your family doctor.

questions.question_text: Are you feeling feverish?
Are you discharging fluids from your nose?
Is the inside of your nose red?
Are your eyes watering?
Is your nose runny?
Do you have a sore throat?
Do you have headaches?
Do you have muscle aches?
Are you coughing?
Are you sneezing?
Is your temperature high?
Do you feel pressure in your ears and on your face?
Have you lost your sense of taste and smell?

overview: A common cold is a mild viral infection of the nose, throat, sinuses and upper airways. It is one of the most frequently experienced acute illnesses in the United States and throughout the industrialized world. Adults will develop roughly two to three colds per year. In most cases, a person experiencing a cold will have no need to visit a doctor, as the symptoms will typically clear up on their own in up to 10 days.

treatment.outline: A cold will typically remedy itself in up to 10 days. During this time, the symptoms of a cold can be managed through a combination of self-care techniques and over-the-counter medications. These methods, however, will not shorten the duration of the cold.
self_care: Adjust your room's temperature and humidity
Try saline nasal drops or sprays
treatment.non_emergency: To help manage the symptoms of a cold, the following things may be effective: Adequate fluid intake, Getting plenty of rest, Eating healthily; a diet high in fibre, fruit and vegetables is recommended, Stopping smoking.

name: Conjunctivitis
extras__hint: You should see your family doctor or an ophthalmologist. Viral or bacterial conjunctivitis are very contagious, so remember about personal hygiene to reduce the risk of spreading it to others (avoid touching your eyes, wash your hands often, do not share personal items, such as pillows, towels, eyeglasses).

questions.question_text: Are your eyes discharging fluid?
Do you have Redness and swelling of the conjunctivae?
Are your eyelids red?
Are your eyes red?
Do you have a burning sensation in your eyes?
Do your eyes produce pus that sticks to lashes?
Are your eyes itchy?
Are your eyes watering?

overview: Pink eye (conjunctivitis) is an inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane (conjunctiva) that lines your eyelid and covers the white part of your eyeball. When small blood vessels in the conjunctiva become inflamed, they're more visible. This is what causes the whites of your eyes to appear reddish or pink.

treatment.outline: Pink eye treatment is usually focused on symptom relief. Your doctor may recommend using artificial tears, cleaning your eyelids with a wet cloth, and applying cold or warm compresses several times daily.
self_care: Apply a compress to your eyes
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor may recommend using artificial tears, cleaning your eyelids with a wet cloth, and applying cold or warm compresses several times daily.

name: Contact dermatitis
extras__hint: You should consult a dermatologist.

questions.question_text: Are your existing symptoms getting rapidly worse?
Is your skin producing fluid?
Do you feel increasing pain on your skin?
Are you feeling unwell?
Are you feverish?

causes: Prolonged exposure to water can cause skin irritation, especially if the water contains chlorine or is hard or chalky
Detergents, such as washing-up liquid, laundry soap or bleach
Solvents, such as petrol or chemicals found in the workplace
Certain plants, such as clematis, hellebore and poison ivy
Nickel, a substance common in metal alloys used in everyday items, such as jewellery, clothes and bra straps
Cobalt, a metal sometimes found in jewellery
Chromate, a metal sometimes found in cement mixtures
Cosmetics, such as perfumes, hair dyes and nail varnish
overview: Contact dermatitis is a red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it. The rash isn't contagious or life-threatening, but it can be very uncomfortable.

treatment.outline: If home care steps don't ease your signs and symptoms, your doctor may prescribe medications.
self_care: Apply an anti-itch cream to the affected area
Soak in a comfortable cool bath
treatment.non_emergency: Treating contact dermatitis will typically involve moisturizers, topical corticosteroids and/or steroid tablets. A dermatologist will be able to advise on the best course of treatment for each person. In mild cases, home remedies such as cool baths or cool, wet compresses may be effective in soothing the symptoms of contact dermatitis.

name: Corns and callosities
extras__hint: If a corn or callus becomes very painful or inflamed, see your doctor.

questions.question_text: Do you have a thick, rough area of skin?
Do you have a hardened, raised bump?
Do you feel tenderness or pain under your skin?
Is your skin flaky, dry or waxy?

causes: Playing instruments or using hand tools
overview: Corns and calluses are thick, hardened layers of skin that develop when your skin tries to protect itself against friction and pressure. They most often develop on the feet and toes or hands and fingers. Corns and calluses can be unsightly.

treatment.outline: Treatment for corns and calluses usually involves avoiding the repetitive actions that caused them to develop. You can help resolve them by wearing properly fitting shoes, using protective pads and taking other self-care measures.
treatment.emergency: In rare instances, your doctor may recommend surgery to correct the alignment of a bone causing friction.
treatment.non_emergency: If a corn or callus persists or becomes painful despite your self-care efforts, the following medical treatments can provide relief: trimming away excess skin, callus-removing medication or shoe inserts.

name: Costochondritis
extras__hint: See your family doctor. You may also need to consult a traumatologist.

questions.question_text: Do you feel pain in a particular posture, such as lying down?
Is there pressure on your chest when you wear a seatbelt or hug someone?
Are you coughing and sneezing?
Do you feel pain during physical activity?

overview: Costochondritis (kos-toe-kon-DRY-tis) is an inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the breastbone (sternum). Pain caused by costochondritis might mimic that of a heart attack or other heart conditions.

treatment.outline: Costochondritis usually goes away on its own, although it might last for several weeks or longer. Treatment focuses on pain relief.
self_care: Use over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs pain relievers
treatment.emergency: If conservative measures don't work, your doctor might suggest injecting numbing medication and a corticosteroid directly into the painful joint.
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment for Costochondritis focuses on pain relief. This includes medication and physical therapy treatments such as stretching exercises and nerve stimulation.

name: Cough, unspecified
extras__hint: If your symptoms get worse, see your family doctor.

questions.question_text: Is your nose runny or stuffy?
Do you have a feeling of liquid running down the back of your throat?
Is your throat sore?
Does your voice sound raspy or strained?
Are you wheezing?
Do you have heartburn or a sour taste in your mouth?
Are you coughing up blood?

causes: Inhaling an irritant (such as smoke, dust, chemicals or a foreign body)
overview: A chronic cough is a cough that lasts eight weeks or longer in adults, or four weeks in children.

treatment.outline: Determining the cause of chronic cough is crucial to effective treatment. In many cases, more than one underlying condition may be causing your chronic cough.
self_care: Suck on cough drops or hard candies
treatment.non_emergency: If you are currently smoking, your doctor will discuss with you your readiness to quit and provide assistance to achieve this goal. If you're taking an ACE inhibitor medication, your doctor may switch you to another medicine that doesn't have cough as a side effect.

name: Degenerative disc disease of the lumbar and sacral spine
common_name: Degenerative disc disease of the lumbar and sacral spine
extras__hint: It would be a good idea to see an orthopedist or a neurologist.

questions.question_text: Are you feeling pain in your lower back, buttocks, or upper thighs?
Do you have a nagging or severe pain that comes and goes?
Do you have pain that feels worse when you sit, and better when you move and walk?
Do you have pain that feels worse when you bend, lift, or twist?
Do you have pain that gets better when you change positions or lie down?

overview: Degenerative disc disease is an age-related condition that happens when one or more of the discs between the vertebrae of the spinal column deteriorates or breaks down, leading to pain. There may be weakness, numbness, and pain that radiates down the leg.

treatment.outline: Treatment may include occupational therapy, physical therapy, or both, special exercises, medications, losing weight, and surgery.
treatment.non_emergency: Initial pain management methods for degenerative disc pain typically include: Over-the-counter pain medications, Prescription pain medications, Heat and Ice, Manual manipulation, Massage therapy or Epidural steriod injections. Physical therapy is also often suggested to help maintain healthy mobility in the spine.

name: Dehydration
extras__hint: Please consult your family doctor.

questions.question_text: Are you feeling thirsty?
Is your pee dark yellow and strong-smelling?
Are you feeling dizzy or lightheaded?
Are you feeling tired?
Are your eyes, lips or mouth dry?
Are you peeing little, and fewer than 4 times a day?
Do you have diabetes?
Do you have diarrhoea?
Have you been in the sun for too long?
Have you drunk too much alcohol?
Have you sweated too much after exercising?
Do you have a high temperature of 38°C or more?
Have you been taking medicines that make you pee more?

overview: Dehydration means your body loses more fluids than you take in. If it's not treated, it can get worse and become a serious problem. Babies, children and the elderly are more at risk of dehydration.

treatment.outline: The best approach to dehydration treatment depends on age, the severity of dehydration and its cause.
treatment.emergency: Children and adults who are severely dehydrated should be treated by emergency personnel arriving in an ambulance or in a hospital emergency room. Salts and fluids delivered through a vein (intravenously) are absorbed quickly and speed recovery.
treatment.non_emergency: For infants and children who have become dehydrated from diarrhea, vomiting or fever, use an over-the-counter oral rehydration solution. These solutions contain water and salts in specific proportions to replenish both fluids and electrolytes. Older children can be given diluted sports drinks. Most adults with mild to moderate dehydration from diarrhea, vomiting or fever can improve their condition by drinking more water or other liquids. Diarrhea may be worsened by full-strength fruit juice and soft drinks. If you work or exercise outdoors during hot or humid weather, cool water is your best bet. Sports drinks containing electrolytes and a carbohydrate solution also may be helpful.

name: Dental caries
extras__hint: Please see your dentist.

questions.question_text: Is there a hole or visible black spot on any surface of your tooth?
Is the affected tooth tender on percussion?

causes: Acid demineralisation of hard tooth surface
overview: Cavities (dental caries) are permanently damaged areas in teeth that develop into tiny holes. Causes include bacteria, snacking, sipping sugary drinks, and poor teeth cleaning. Untreated, they can cause toothache, infection, and tooth loss.

treatment.outline: Regular checkups can identify cavities and other dental conditions before they cause troubling symptoms and lead to more-serious problems. The sooner you seek care, the better your chances of reversing the earliest stages of tooth decay and preventing its progression. If a cavity is treated before it starts causing pain, you probably won't need extensive treatment.
self_care: Take an over-the-counter pain reliever, if your doctor has said it's OK for you
Use an over-the-counter anesthetic specifically designed to soothe painful teeth
Use warm water to brush your teeth
Use toothpaste designed for sensitive teeth
Thoroughly clean all parts of your mouth and teeth — don't avoid painful areas
Avoid foods or beverages that are hot, cold or sweet enough to trigger pain
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment of cavities depends on how severe they are and your particular situation. Treatment options include: Fluoride treatments, Fillings, Crowns, Root canals or Tooth extractions.

name: Diarrhea, unspecified
extras__hint: Please, contact your family doctor if your symptoms don't get better in one day.

questions.question_text: Do you have Anaemia?
Have you lost weight?
Do you have anorexia?
Do you have oral lesions e.g. oral ulcers, candidiasis?
Do you have skin lesions e.g. erythema nodosum?
Are you dehydrated?
Is your thyroid enlarged?
Is there a growth or swelling in your abdomen?
Do you have an abnormal swelling in your rectum?

causes: Chronic infections: e.g. amoebiasis, tuberculosis, opportunistic infections with HIV
Endocrine: e.g. hyperthyroidism, diabetic autonomic neuropathy
overview: Diarrhea - loose, watery and possibly more-frequent bowel movements - is a common problem. Luckily, diarrhea is usually short-lived, lasting no more than a few days. But, when diarrhea lasts for weeks, it usually indicates that's there's another problem. If you have diarrhea for weeks or longer, you may have a condition such as irritable bowel disorder, or a more serious disorder, such as a persistent infection or inflammatory bowel disease.

treatment.outline: Most cases of diarrhea clear on their own within a couple of days without treatment. If you've tried lifestyle changes and home remedies for diarrhea without success, your doctor might recommend medications or other treatments.
self_care: Drink plenty of clear liquids, including water, broths and juices. Avoid caffeine and alcohol.
Add semisolid and low-fiber foods gradually as your bowel movements return to normal. Try soda crackers, toast, eggs, rice or chicken.
Avoid certain foods such as dairy products, fatty foods, high-fiber foods or highly seasoned foods for a few days
treatment.non_emergency: Antibiotics might help treat diarrhea caused by bacteria or parasites. If a virus is causing your diarrhea, antibiotics won't help. Your doctor likely will advise you to place the fluids and salts.

name: Disorder of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, unspecified
extras__hint: Please schedule an appointment with your family doctor or a dermatologist.
causes: Bacteria trapped in skin pores and hair follicles
Fungus, parasites, or microorganisms living on the skin
Contact with allergens, irritants, or another person's infected skin
Illnesses affecting the thyroid, immune system, kidneys, and other body systems
overview: Skin disorders vary greatly in symptoms and severity. They can be temporary or permanent, and may be painless or painful. Some have situational causes, while others may be genetic. Some skin conditions are minor, and others can be life-threatening. While most skin disorders are minor, others can indicate a more serious issue. Contact your doctor if you think you might have one of these common skin problems.

treatment.outline: Many skin disorders are treatable.
treatment.non_emergency: Common treatment methods for skin conditions include: antihistamines, medicated creams and ointments, antibiotics, vitamin or steroid injections, laser therapy and targeted prescription medications. Not all skin disorders respond to treatment. Some conditions go away without treatment. People with permanent skin conditions often go through periods of severe symptoms. Sometimes people are able to force incurable conditions into remission. However, most skin conditions reappear due to certain triggers, such as stress or illness.

name: Dry eye disease
extras__hint: Try to use hydrating eye drops daily. If this doesn't help, consult your general practitioner.

questions.question_text: Are your eyes irritated and red?
Are your eyes dry and gritty?
Are your eyes discharging mucus?
Is your vision blurred temporarily?
Are your eyes itchy?
Are you sensitive to light?
Do you feel the sensation of a foreign-body in your eye?
Are you producing tears excessively?

causes: The glands of the eyes are unable to create an adequate amount of tears
There is an imbalance in the composition of the tears
Underlying medical conditions, including Sjogren syndrome, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroid disorders and vitamin A deficiency

Certain medications including decongestants, antihistamines, hormone replacement therapy and antidepressants; medications used to treat high blood pressure, acne and Parkinsons disease, as well as birth control drugs
Damage to the tear glands from inflammation or radiation
Dry, windy, smoky or air-conditioned environments
Blinking less often, typically when reading, driving, watching TV or using a computer
Problems with the eyelids, such as ectropion, an out-turning of the eyelids, or entropion, an in-turning of the eyelids
Lipid: The oily outer layer produced by the meibomian glands. Prevents tears from evaporating too quickly.
Aqueous: The watery middle layer produced by the tear glands. Helps to nourish the cornea and the conjunctiva.
Mucus: The inner layer produced by goblet cells. Aids in binding water to the eyes, helping them to stay moist.
overview: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca, also known as dry eye syndrome, is a common dysfunction of the eyes. It occurs when the eyes cannot produce tears or produce insufficient quantities of tears, or when there is an imbalance in the amount of oil, water and mucus in the tear fluid.

treatment.outline: For most people with occasional or mild dry eye symptoms, it's enough to regularly use over-the-counter eyedrops (artificial tears).
treatment.non_emergency: For most people with occasional or mild dry eye symptoms, it's enough to regularly use over-the-counter eyedrops (artificial tears). If your symptoms are persistent and more serious, you have other options. What you do depends on what's causing your dry eyes. Some treatments focus on reversing or managing a condition or factor that's causing your dry eyes. Other treatments can improve your tear quality or stop your tears from quickly draining away from your eyes.
medication: Eye inserts that work like artificial tears
Eyedrops made from your own blood

name: Dysmenorrhea
extras__hint: You should see a gynecologist, and you may also have to consult an endocrinologist.

questions.question_text: Are you cramping in your lower abdomen?
Do you feel pain in your lower abdomen?
Do you have low back pain?
Do you feel pain radiating down the legs?
Are you feeling nauseous?
Are you vomiting?
Do you have Diarrhea?
Are you fatigued?
Are you weak?
Are you fainting?
Do you have headaches?

causes: Infection, tumors, or polyps in the pelvic cavity
overview: Some pain, cramping, and discomfort during menstrual periods is normal. Excessive pain that causes you to miss work or school is not. Painful menstruation is also called dysmenorrhea. There are two types of dysmenorrhea: primary and secondary. Primary dysmenorrhea occurs in people who experience pain before and during menstruation. If you've had normal periods that become painful later in life, it may be secondary dysmenorrhea.

treatment.outline: To ease your menstrual cramps, your doctor might recommend: Pain relievers, Hormonal birth control or Surgery
treatment.emergency: If your menstrual cramps are caused by a disorder such as endometriosis or fibroids, surgery to correct the problem might help your symptoms. Surgical removal of the uterus also might be an option if other approaches fail to ease your symptoms and if you're not planning to have children.
treatment.non_emergency: To ease your menstrual cramps, your doctor might recommend: Pain relievers or Hormonal birth control to prevent ovulation and reduce the severity of menstrual cramps

name: Earwax blockage
extras__hint: You should consult otolaryngologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have earaches?
Does the affected ear feel full?
Do you hear ringing or noises in your ear (tinnitus)?
Has your hearing decreased in the affected ear?
Are you dizzy?
Are you coughing?

overview: Earwax blockage occurs when earwax (cerumen) accumulates in your ear or becomes too hard to wash away naturally.

treatment.outline: If earwax blockage becomes a problem, you or your doctor can take simple steps to remove the wax safely.
self_care: Soften the wax by applying a few drops of baby oil, mineral oil, glycerin or diluted hydrogen peroxide in your ear canal
Squirt warm water into your ear canal
Dry the ear canal with a towel or hand-held dryer
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor can remove excess wax using a small, curved instrument called a curet or by using suction while inspecting the ear. Your doctor can also flush out the wax using a water pick or a rubber-bulb syringe filled with warm water. If earwax buildup is a recurring problem, your doctor may recommend that you use a wax-removal medication, such as carbamide peroxide (Debrox Earwax Removal Kit, Murine Ear Wax Removal System). Because these drops can irritate the delicate skin of the eardrum and ear canal, use them only as directed.

name: Endometrial polyp
extras__hint: You should see a gynaecologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have Irregular menstrual bleeding - for example, having frequent, unpredictable periods of variable length and heaviness?
Are you bleeding between menstrual periods?
Are your menstrual periods excessively heavy?
Are you experiencing vaginal bleeding after menopause?
Are you infertile?

overview: Endometrial polyps, also called uterine polyps, are growths in the interior of the uterus or womb, formed of an overgrowth of the cells (endometrium) that line this cavity. They may occur alone or in clusters and are typically less than a centimeter in diameter, but in rare cases can grow much larger for example, to the size of a golf ball or an orange. Polyps are more common in people who have not yet experienced menopause than those who have. They rarely occur in adolescents. Endometrial polyps can affect a womans fertility and, in rare cases, be linked to cancer.

treatment.outline: Small, asymptomatic polyps in people before menopause often require no treatment, but will instead be monitored for changes or an increase in symptoms.
treatment.emergency: Uterine polyp removal, called a polypectomy, which is carried out using a hysteroscopy, is the standard procedure. The doctor uses a camera attached to a long, thin tube to examine the interior of the uterus, locate the polyp and then remove it with an integrated wire loop or blade. It is typically screened for cancer. The removal of small endometrial polyps using hysteroscopy can sometimes be done as an outpatient procedure at a doctors office, but removing large polyps may require a hospital stay. Many people are able to return to normal activities within the next few days. Side-effects of uterine polyp removal may include light spotting
treatment.non_emergency: For endometrial polyps, your doctor might recommend: watchful waiting or medication. Medication is usually a short-term solution at best — symptoms typically recur once you stop taking the medicine.

name: Epistaxis
extras__hint: Try basic self care measures, pinch your nose just above your nostrils for 10 to 15 minutes or place an icepack at the top of your nose. If those doesn't help or bleeding is profound, please report to an outpatient clinic.

questions.question_text: Is your nose bleeding?
Are you experiencing signs related to hypertension?
Are you experiencing signs of shock?

causes: Picking of the nose, especially when there is an upper respiratory tract infection
overview: Epistaxis (also called a nosebleed) refers to a minor bleeding from the blood vessels of the nose. Epistaxis is a commonly-found complaint, especially in fields of emergency medicine related to the treatment of ear, nose, and throat (ENT) conditions

treatment.outline: Most nosebleeds aren't serious and will stop on their own or by following self-care steps.
self_care: If the bleeding doesn't stop, repeat the steps for up to a total of 15 minutes
treatment.emergency: Seek emergency medical care if nosebleeds follow an injury, involve a greater than expected amount of blood, interfere with breathing, last longer than 30 minutes even with compression, occur in chldren younger than age 2. Treatments to be considered include topical vasoconstriction, chemical cautery, electrocautery, nasal packing (nasal tampon or gauze impregnated with petroleum jelly), posterior gauze packing, use of a balloon system (including a modified Foley catheter), and arterial ligation or embolization.

name: Extrasystoles
extras__hint: Please see a cardiologist, who will evaluate your condition.

questions.question_text: Is your heartbeat strong and irregular?
Are you feeling trepidatious or anxious?
Do you have chest pain?
Are you experiencing respiratory distress?
Do you have Stomach upset or increased urge to urinate?
Are you experiencing headache or nausea?

causes: Heavy consumption of alcohol, nicotine or coffee
overview: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that begin in one of your heart's two lower pumping chambers (ventricles). These extra beats disrupt your regular heart rhythm, sometimes causing you to feel a fluttering or a skipped beat in your chest.

treatment.outline: For most people, PVCs with an otherwise normal heart won't need treatment.
treatment.emergency: In some cases, if you have heart disease that could lead to more-serious rhythm problems, you might need the following: Lifestyle changes, Medications or Radiofrequency catheter ablation.
treatment.non_emergency: If you have frequent PVCs, your doctor might recommend treatment.

name: Fatigue
extras__hint: Please see your family doctor or an internist.

questions.question_text: Do you have problems sleeping?
Do you have insomnia?
Do you have muscle or joint pain?
Do you have headaches?
Do you have a sore throat or sore glands that are not swollen?
Do you have problems thinking, remembering or concentrating?
Do you have flu-like symptoms?
Are you feeling dizzy or sick?
Are your heartbeats fast or irregular?
Are you able to carry out everyday activities, such as work, studies or housework, but with difficulty?
Do you have difficulty moving around easily and problems carrying out daily activities?
Are you only able to perform very basic daily tasks?

causes: taking certain medications, such as antidepressants or sedatives
using alcohol on a regular basis
using illicit drugs, such as cocaine
infections, such as cold and flu
Addison's disease, a disorder that can affect your hormone levels
overview: Fatigue is a term used to describe an overall feeling of tiredness or lack of energy. It isn’t the same as simply feeling drowsy or sleepy. When you’re fatigued, you have no motivation and no energy. Being sleepy may be a symptom of fatigue, but it’s not the same thing.

treatment.outline: There is no cure for fatigue. Treatment focuses on symptom relief. The most disruptive or disabling symptoms should be addressed first.
self_care: Drink enough fluids to stay hydrated
Avoid a work or social schedule that's overly demanding
Take part in relaxing activities such as yoga
Abstain from alcohol, tobacco, and other illicit drugs

name: Fibrocystic breasts
extras__hint: Please consult a gynecologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have breast lumps?
Do you feel pain or tenderness or discomfort in the upper outer part of your breasts?
Do you have breast nodules?
Do your nipples leak green or dark brown nonbloody fluid without pressure?
Have you experienced changes that are similar in both breasts?
Do you have a monthly increase in breast pain or lumpiness from ovulation to just before your period and then gets better once your period starts?

causes: Women who have not yet had a child
higher age at birth of first child
Women who have given birth to several children
Treatment with tamoxifen (a drug from breast cancer treatment)
overview: Fibrocystic breasts are composed of tissue that feels lumpy or ropelike in texture. Doctors call this nodular or glandular breast tissue.

treatment.outline: Most women affected by fibrocystic mastopathy do not require specific treatment. However, if symptoms are found to be restrictive, the symptoms can be specifically treated and thus alleviated.
self_care: Wear a sports bra during exercise and while sleeping
Reduce or stop taking gormone therapy if you're postmenopausal
Use a heating pad or warm water bottle to relieve your discomfort
treatment.non_emergency: The following can help with pain in the breasts: Wearing a supporting bra, Taking over-the-counter painkillers temporarily and with consultation with a doctor or pharmacist, Warm compresses can be tried out individually, Diet changes such as reduction of the intake of caffeinated beverages, reduction of food with high salt content and adopting a fibre-rich, low-fat diet, Hormone therapy for severe pain lasting at least 6 months and in consultation with the attending physician, Puncturing of simple cysts that cause symptoms with a biopsy needle under ultrasound control.

name: Food poisoning
extras__hint: If you feel very sick, see a doctor.

questions.question_text: Are you vomiting?
Do you have stomach pains?
Are you confused?
Are you experiencing drowsiness and fainting fits?
Are you feeling sick?
Do you have diarrhoea?
Do you have stomach pain?
Are you drowsy?
Do you have a high temperature of 38C (100.4F) or above ?
Are you shivering?
Have you lost your appetite?
Do you have a headache?
Are you irritable?
Do you have difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)?
Do you have breathing difficulties?
Are you producing more saliva than normal?
Do you have a skin rash ?
Do you have blue lips and skin (cyanosis)?
Are there burns around your nose or mouth?
Is your vision blurred?
Are you confused?
Do you have seizures?
Are you losing consciousness?
Are you in a coma?

overview: Food poisoning, also called foodborne illness, is illness caused by eating contaminated food. Infectious organisms - including bacteria, viruses and parasites - or their toxins are the most common causes of food poisoning.

treatment.outline: Treatment for food poisoning typically depends on the source of the illness, if known, and the severity of your symptoms. For most people, the illness resolves without treatment within a few days, though some types of food poisoning may last longer.
self_care: Try sucking on ice chips or taking small sips of water
Avoid certain foods and substances until you're feeling better
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment of food poisoning may include: Replacement of lost fluids or Antibiotics.

name: Functional dyspepsia
extras__hint: Please see a gastroenterologist.

questions.question_text: Are you experiencing a painful burning feeling in the chest, often after eating?
Do you feel full and bloated?
Are you feeling sick?
Are you belching and farting?
Are you bringing up food or bitter-tasting fluids into your mouth?

causes: Infection with the germ Helicobacter pylori (not all people with the condition will have Helicobacter pylori in their stomach, and many people with the Helicobacter pylori germ will experience no symptoms)
Impairment of the stomach muscles, leading to slowed emptying of the stomach into the duodenum (first segment of the small intestine)

Roughly one in three people with the disorder also experience irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The cause of IBS, however, is unknown, meaning that the possible link between IBS and indigestion has not yet been properly established
overview: Functional dyspepsia (dis-PEP-see-uh) is a term for recurring signs and symptoms of indigestion that have no obvious cause. Functional dyspepsia is also called nonulcer stomach pain or nonulcer dyspepsia.

treatment.outline: Functional dyspepsia cannot be fully cured, but its symptoms can be successfully managed through lifestyle changes, medication, or a combination of the two.
self_care: Chew your food slowly and thoroughly
treatment.non_emergency: Functional dyspepsia cannot be fully cured, but its symptoms can be successfully managed through lifestyle changes, medication, or a combination of the two.

name: Gambling addiction
extras__hint: Please see a psychologist or psychiatrist.

questions.question_text: Are you preoccupied with gambling, such as constantly planning how to get more gambling money?
Do feel the need to gamble with increasing amounts of money to get the same thrill?
Have you been trying to control, cut back or stop gambling, without success?
Do you feel restless or irritable when you try to cut down on gambling?
Do use gambling to escape problems or relieve feelings of helplessness, guilt, anxiety or depression?
Have you been trying to get back lost money by gambling more (chasing losses)?
Have you been lying to family members or others to hide the extent of your gambling?
Have you been jeopardizing or losing important relationships, a job, or school or work opportunities because of gambling?
Do you resort to theft or fraud to get gambling money?
Do you ask others to bail you out of financial trouble because you gambled money away?

overview: Compulsive gambling, also called gambling disorder, is the uncontrollable urge to keep gambling despite the toll it takes on your life. Gambling means that you're willing to risk something you value in the hope of getting something of even greater value.

treatment.outline: Treating compulsive gambling can be challenging. That's partly because most people have a hard time admitting they have a problem.
treatment.non_emergency: Treatment for compulsive gambling may include: Therapy, Medications or Self-help groups

name: Gastritis
extras__hint: Please see an internist or a gastroenterologist.

Do you have gnawing or burning stomach pain?
Are you feeling sick?
Do you feel full after eating?

This is one the most common causes of acute and chronic gastritis.

overview: Gastritis is a general term for a group of conditions with one thing in common: inflammation of the lining of the stomach. The inflammation of gastritis is most often the result of infection with the same bacterium that causes most stomach ulcers.

treatment.outline: Treatment of gastritis depends on the specific cause.
treatment.non_emergency: Acute gastritis caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or alcohol may be relieved by stopping use of those substances.
medication: Medications that block acid production and promote healing

name: Gastroesophageal reflux disease
extras__hint: Please see your family doctor or a gastroenterologist.

questions.question_text: Do you have stomach pain?
Do you have feel pain when swallowing and an acidic taste in the mouth?
Are you bloated?
Do you get full quickly?
Do you have bad breath?
Do you feel a non-burning chest pain?
Is your voice hoarse?
Are you vomiting or nauseous?
Do you bring up food after swallowing?
Are you coughing and wheezing?
Do you have a persistent sore throat?
Do you feel a lump in your throat that is present despite swallowing?
Is the enamel on your teeth eroded?

causes: People who smoke tobacco and drink alcohol and/or coffee regularly
People who are under high levels of stress
People with hiatus hernia, a condition involving part of the stomach pushing through the diaphragm
People with certain other gastrointestinal conditions, like some malformations
People with scleroderma, a rare condition that can cause the skin and internal organs to become thicker and hardened
overview: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) occurs when stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of your esophagus.

treatment.outline: The treatment method used for gastroesophageal reflux disease will depend on the severity of the condition. Mild cases will usually be treated with lifestyle changes and over-the-counter medication.
self_care: Elevate the head of your bed
Don't lie down after a meal
Eat food slowly and chew thoroughly
Avoid foods and drinks that trigger reflux
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor is likely to recommend that you first try lifestyle modifications and over-the-counter medications. If you don't experience relief within a few weeks, your doctor might recommend prescription medication or surgery.
medication: Medications that block acid production and heal the esophagus
Medication to strengthen the lower esophageal sphincter

name: General anxiety disorder
extras__hint: Please consult a psychologist or a psychiatrist.

questions.question_text: Do you experience excessive anxiety and worry that it is present on more days than not?
Do you experience anxiety that significantly interferes with daily life, affecting things such as attention to tasks and normal social and occupational functioning?
Do you have anxiety or worry that it is stronger than is appropriate for the situation?
Do you have anxiety or worry that it is focused on various events or activities?
Do you find it difficult controlling the feelings of anxiety?
Do you have worries that may change over time?
Do you experience physical manifestations of anxiety, such as restlessness, muscle tension, irritability and sleep disturbances?
Do you have work issues?
Do you have health issues?
Do you have family and other relationship issues?
Do you have safety issues?
Do you have financial issues?
Do you have with your academic performance?
Do you have issues with sporting events at school?
Have you experienced natural disasters?

causes: Having blood relatives with an anxiety disorder
overview: It's normal to feel anxious from time to time, especially if your life is stressful. However, excessive, ongoing anxiety and worry that are difficult to control and interfere with day-to-day activities may be a sign of generalized anxiety disorder.

treatment.outline: Treatment decisions are based on how significantly generalized anxiety disorder is affecting your ability to function in your daily life.
self_care: Quit smoking and cut back or quit drinking caffeinated beverages
treatment.non_emergency: The two main treatments for generalized anxiety disorder are psychotherapy and medications. Psychotherapy involves working with a therapist to reduce your anxiety symptoms. Medications that can be used include: Antidepressants, Busiprone and Benzodiazepinese.

name: Gingivitis
extras__hint: You should see a dentist.

questions.question_text: Do you have crater-like ulcers and necrosis mainly limited to gum margin and inter-dental gingiva?
Do you have poor oral hygiene?
Are you feverish?
Are your lymph nodes swollen?

causes: Host factors of poor oral hygiene, cigarette smoking and immune-suppression
overview: Gingivitis is a form of gum disease that causes inflamed gums. The cause is poor oral hygiene. Untreated gingivitis can lead to tooth loss and other serious conditions.

treatment.outline: Prompt treatment usually reverses symptoms of gingivitis and prevents its progression to more serious gum disease and tooth loss. You have the best chance for successful treatment when you also adopt a daily routine of good oral care and stop tobacco use.
self_care: Brush your teeth twice a day or, better yet, after every meal or snack.
Use a soft toothbrush and replace it at least every three to four months.
Consider using an electric toothbrush, which may be more effective at removing plaque and tartar.
Use a mouth rinse to help reduce plaque between your teeth.
Supplement brushing and flossing with an interdental cleaner, such as a dental pick, interdental brush or dental stick specially designed to clean between your teeth.
Get regular professional dental cleanings on a schedule recommended by your dentist.
treatment.non_emergency: Professional gingivitis care includes: Professional dental cleaning, Dental restoration, if needed or Ongoing care. If you're consistent with your home oral hygiene, you should see the return of pink, healthy gum tissue within days or weeks.

name: Hemorrhoids
extras__hint: You will need to see a proctologist or a gastroenterologist.

questions.question_text: Are there redundant folds of skin near the position of the haemorrhoids?
Does straining reveal the haemorrhoids?
Do you have swellings at your anus?
Are there palpable thrombosed internal haemorrhoids upon rectal examination?*
Do you experience signs of complications (profuse bleeding with anaemia or haemorrhagic shock, prolapse, strangulation, thrombosis, infection or ulceration)?
Are you pale?

causes: Increased intra-abdominal pressure e.g. chronic cough, pregnancy, intra-abdominal or pelvic tumours
Excessive straining at stools from constipation or diarrhoea
Chronic liver disease with portal hypertension
overview: Hemorrhoids, also known as piles, are swellings that occur when the blood vessels in and around the lower rectum and anal canal become enlarged or swollen. This may cause itching, bleeding and discomfort, though in some cases, no symptoms at all may be present.

treatment.outline: One initial method is to take steps to avoid constipation, and not straining when using the bathroom. However, there are a variety of treatment methods for hemorrhoids.
self_care: Soak regularly in a warm bath or sitz bath
treatment.non_emergency: Various types of creams and ointments are available to help manage the symptoms of hemorrhoids. Some creams and ointments contain anesthetic that is able to soothe pain and irritation.

causes: Viruses (Hepatitis A, B, C, D and E)
Viruses (Hepatitis A, B, C, D and E)
overview: Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver. Inflammation is swelling that happens when tissues of the body are injured or infected. It can damage your liver. This swelling and damage can affect how well your liver functions. Hepatitis can be an acute (short-term) infection or a chronic (long-term) infection.

treatment.outline: Treatment options are determined by which type of hepatitis you have and whether the infection is acute or chronic.

overview: Cold sores — also called fever blisters — are a common viral infection. They are tiny, fluid-filled blisters on and around your lips. These blisters are often grouped together in patches.

treatment.outline: Cold sores generally clear up without treatment in two to four weeks.
treatment.non_emergency: Several types of prescription antiviral medications may speed the healing process. Examples include: Acyclovir (Zovirax), Valacyclovir (Valtrex), Famciclovir, Penciclovir (Denavir)

name: Hives
extras__hint: Please see a dermatologist or allergist.

causes: Some food (especially peanuts, eggs, nuts and shellfish)
Medications, such as antibiotics (especially penicillin and sulfa), aspirin and ibuprofen
Physical stimuli, such as pressure, cold, heat, exercise or sun exposure
Bacterial infections, including urinary tract infections and strep throat
Viral infections, including the common cold, infectious mononucleosis and hepatitis
overview: Hives, itchy welts on the skin, are typically an allergic reaction to certain foods, medications, or other irritants.

treatment.outline: Hives usually clear on their own in 24 hours. Your doctor will likely recommend you treat your symptoms with home remedies, such as over-the-counter antihistamines.
treatment.non_emergency: Your doctor will likely recommend you treat your symptoms with home remedies, such as over-the-counter antihistamines. If self-care steps don't help, talk with your doctor about finding the prescription medication or combination of drugs that works best for you. Usually, an effective treatment can be found.
medication: Drugs that suppress the immune system

name: Hydrocele testis
